Standard models of degree 111 del Pezzo fibrations

Konstantin Loginov
Abstract.

We construct a standard birational model (a model that has Gorenstein canonical singularities) for the three-dimensional del Pezzo fibrations Ï€:XâŸ¶C:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğ¶{\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C} of degree 111 and relative Picard number 111. We also embed the standard model into the relative weighted projective space â„™Câ€‹(1,1,2,3)subscriptâ„™ğ¶1123\mathbb{P}_{C}(1,1,2,3). Our construction works in the GğºG-equivariant category whereÂ GğºG is a finite group.

Introduction

The Minimal Model Program (the MMP for short, see [Ma02], [KMM87]) is a powerful tool that helps to understand the birational properties of algebraic varieties. The minimal category in which it works is the category ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} of the projective varieties with at worst terminal â„šâ„š\mathbb{Q}-factorial singularities. The result of applying this program to a projective variety is either a minimal model, that is a variety Xâˆˆğ’ğ‘‹ğ’X\in\mathcal{C} whose canonical divisor class KXsubscriptğ¾ğ‘‹K_{X} is nef, or a Fanoâ€“Mori fibration, that is a variety Xâˆˆğ’ğ‘‹ğ’X\in\mathcal{C} admitting a contraction morphism Ï€:XâŸ¶B:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğµ\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B whose fibers are of positive dimension, the anti-canonical divisor class âˆ’KXsubscriptğ¾ğ‘‹-K_{X} is relatively ample, and Ïâ€‹(X/B)=1ğœŒğ‘‹ğµ1\rho(X/B)=1.

We will focus on the three-dimensional case. In this case, the base BğµB of the Fanoâ€“Mori fibration Ï€:XâŸ¶B:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğµ\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B can be of dimension 00, 111 or 222. If dimB=0dimensionğµ0\dim B=0 then Xğ‘‹X is a (possibly singular) Fano variety. It is known that Fano varieties lie in a finite number of algebraic families. However, they are classified only in the smooth case. In the singular case there are partial classificational results (see e.g. [Pr16a]).

If dimB=2dimensionğµ2\dim B=2 then a general fiber of Ï€ğœ‹\pi is a non-singular rational curve. In this case, Ï€:XâŸ¶B:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğµ\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B is called a â„šâ„š\mathbb{Q}-conic fibration. It is known that in this case there exists a standard model, that is a â„šâ„š\mathbb{Q}-conic fibration Ï€â€²:Xâ€²âŸ¶Bâ€²:superscriptğœ‹â€²âŸ¶superscriptğ‘‹â€²superscriptğµâ€²\pi^{\prime}\colon X^{\prime}\longrightarrow B^{\prime} where Xâ€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²X^{\prime} and Bâ€²superscriptğµâ€²B^{\prime} are non-singular, Xâ€²superscriptğ‘‹â€²X^{\prime} is fiberwise birationally equivalent to Xğ‘‹X, and Ïâ€‹(Xâ€²/Bâ€²)=1ğœŒsuperscriptğ‘‹â€²superscriptğµâ€²1\rho(X^{\prime}/B^{\prime})=1 (see [Sa82]).

Finally, if dimB=1dimensionğµ1\dim B=1 then a general fiber of Ï€ğœ‹\pi is a non-singular del Pezzo surface. In this situation the fibration Ï€:XâŸ¶B:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğµ\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B is called a â„šâ„š\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration. Standard models of such fibrations were considered in the work of A.Â Corti [Co96], see also [Ko97].

For the applications to the problem of classification of the finite subgroups in the Cremona group (see e. g. [PrSh16]), as well as for birational classification of varieties over algebraically non-closed fields one should change the category ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}. We will work with the varieties defined over an arbitrary field of characteristic 00 that admit an action of a finite group GğºG. In this case, we can apply the GğºG-equivariant Minimal Model Program (the GğºG-MMP, see [KM98, 2.18, 2.19], [Mo88, 0.3.14]). Again, a final product of applying this program can be either a GğºG-minimal model, or a GğºG-Fanoâ€“Mori fibration. For a three-dimensional GğºG-Fanoâ€“Mori fibration Ï€:XâŸ¶B:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğµ\pi\colon X\longrightarrow B, as in the â€œclassicalâ€ situation, we have three possibilities:

  • â€¢

    Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-Fano varieties. In general, this class is poorly understood. Partial results can be found in the works [Pr15], [Pr16], [Pr16a], [PrSh16].

  • â€¢

    Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-conic fibrations. In this case existence of the standard model is proven in the work [Av14].

  • â€¢

    Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibrations (see Definition 1.5). In the present work, we construct standard models of Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibrations of degree 111.

The following theorems are the main results of this paper (the necessary definitions are given in Â§1).

We prove these results in several steps. First, in Â§1, Proposition 1.7, we give the main definitions and prove some preliminary results. 1. Preliminaries

We work over a field of characteristic 00, not necessarily algebraically closed. We also fix a finite group GğºG. Recall the standard definitions.

Definition 1.1.

An algebraic variety Xğ‘‹X is called a GğºG-variety (or a variety with an action of the group GğºG) if there exists a homomorphism (not necessarily injective)

Definition 1.3.

We introduce the main definitions.

Definition 1.4.

A del Pezzo surface Sğ‘†S is a (not necessarily normal) projective surface that has at worst Gorenstein singularities and whose anti-canonical divisor classÂ âˆ’KSsubscriptğ¾ğ‘†-K_{S} is ample. The degree of a del Pezzo surface Sğ‘†S is the number (âˆ’KS)2superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘†2(-K_{S})^{2}.

Definition 1.5.

Let Xğ‘‹X be a three-dimensional normal projective GğºG-variety with at worst terminal singularities and let Cğ¶C be a non-singular GğºG-curve. Assume that

  1. (i)

    Xğ‘‹X is Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-factorial;

    there exists a projective GğºG-morphism with connected fibers Ï€:XâŸ¶C:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğ¶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C;

  3. (iii)

    âˆ’KXsubscriptğ¾ğ‘‹-K_{X} is Ï€ğœ‹\pi-ample;

    Ï€ğœ‹\pi is an extremal contraction, that is ÏGâ€‹(X/C)=1superscriptğœŒğºğ‘‹ğ¶1\rho^{G}(X/C)=1.

Then Ï€:XâŸ¶C:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğ¶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C is called a Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration. The degree of a Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration is the degree of its generic fiber XÎ·subscriptğ‘‹ğœ‚X_{\eta}. Since Xğ‘‹X is terminal XÎ·subscriptğ‘‹ğœ‚X_{\eta} is a non-singular del Pezzo surface. If Xğ‘‹X has Gorenstein singularities we call Ï€:XâŸ¶C:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğ¶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C a GğºG-del Pezzo fibration.

Definition 1.6.

We call Ï€:XâŸ¶C:ğœ‹âŸ¶ğ‘‹ğ¶\pi\colon X\longrightarrow C a generalised Gâ€‹â„šğºâ„šG\mathbb{Q}-del Pezzo fibration if Xğ‘‹X has at worst canonical singularities and the conditions (ii) and (iii) of the definition 1.5 are satisfied. Notice that in this case the generic fiber XÎ·subscriptğ‘‹ğœ‚X_{\eta} can be singular.

We will work with the anticanonical linear system on Xğ‘‹X.
